title: Using quickinspectR
text: get started, first need load quicksinspectR package session. don’t already installed, can use commented code install devtools package - lets us install development version quickinspectR straight GitHub. also need load palmerpenguins order access penguins dataset. Let’s ! Great! Now ’re set , can see quickinspectR works.

title: Using quickinspectR
text: design, quickinspectR functions require one argument: data frame tibble (data). Unless otherwise specified, functions display relevant variables contained data frame default easy--read plot styling. Currently, quickinspectR contains three inspect functions: inspect_normality: graphically inspect distribution numeric variables data. inspect_balance: graphically inspect class imbalance among categorical variables. inspect_missing: graphically inspect missingness data. functions can used help familiarize data get analyses ground just bit quicker.

title: Using quickinspectR
text: Let’s say ’m interested exploring relationship body mass, bill length, flipper length using penguins dataset. One first things likely want know start trying intensive analysis “variables normally distributed?” - answer question dictate types analysis can approach analysis. can fumble around dplyr, tidyr, ggplot2 hour trying build plot need ground-, can inspect_normality get fun stuff sooner.  single line code, pretty good sense variables distributed. want get rid clutter plot, can tell inspect_normality variables ’m interested using vars argument.  Using vars argument, can focus variables interested leave variables ’m interested plot.
code: inspect_normality(penguins) #> Warning: Removed 8 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`). inspect_normality(data = penguins,                   vars = c("bill_length_mm", "flipper_length_mm", "body_mass_g")) #> Warning: Removed 6 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`).

text: Now ’ve inspected numeric variables, ’m thinking might connection species penguin, sex, physical attributes. important details want know right away. many different species dealing dataset? enough observations corresponding classification species/sex use meaningfully analysis? undertaking formal analysis, want make sure ’m well-informed . can inspect_balance figure quickly.  single line code, can see ’s pretty even split male female penguins, ’s much less balance different species penguins. ’ll keep mind start trying build models.

text: may noticed NA found way plot. good reminder take look see ’s missing data penguins dataset. data missing patterned way, introduce bias analysis. can inspect_missing figure .  missing data seem sex variable. think ’ll okay, ’ll keep mind start seeing unexpected results later . just like , can use vars select variables ’m interested inspecting.  Now bearings, can move advanced (time-intensive) analysis. Using quickinspectR able accomplish routine inspections just minutes just easy lines code.

title: Using quickinspectR
text: wanted , stop reading right now go use quickinspectR work, sometimes ’s nice add little pop colour visualizations.

title: Using quickinspectR
text: inspect functions quickinspectR contain several additional (optional) arguments make plot customization accessible beginner (experienced programmer ’s rush). vars (seen ) allows easily select variables want visualize. fill_colour lets pick colour choice. title lets add descriptive title plot.  Now can inspect data style! inspect functions contain additional arguments, share basic customization options. see additional arguments particular inspect function , can check documentation running ?inspect_... console, replacing ... function choice. example, running ?inspect_normality reveal additional bins argument lets specify number bins use histogram visualization.
code: inspect_normality(data = penguins,                   vars = c("bill_length_mm", "flipper_length_mm", "body_mass_g"),                   fill_colour = "blue",                   title = "Penguin Attributes") #> Warning: Removed 6 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`).

title: Using quickinspectR
text: quickinspectR intended package help novice R programmers get analyses ground efficiently rather build deeply customized plots, plenty opportunities extend quickinspectR want .

title: Using quickinspectR
text: hood, quickinspectR generating ggplot2 objects. Using ... argument, can pass supported ggplot2 argument directly plot’s “main” geom_ layer. using inspect_normality, arguments passed right geom_histogram layer. using inspect_balance inspect_missing, arguments land geom_bar layer.  Using colour alpha, able add additional customizations plot (beyond explicitly supported inspect_normality).
code: inspect_normality(data = penguins,                   vars = c("bill_length_mm", "flipper_length_mm", "body_mass_g"),                   fill_colour = "navyblue",                   title = "Penguin Attributes",                   colour = "lightblue", # Specifies the bar outline colour                   alpha = 0.7) # Reduces the opacity #> Warning: Removed 6 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`).

title: Using quickinspectR
text: passing additional arguments pre-specified geom layer great, ’s without limitations. Since inspect functions return standard ggplot2 object, can easily add themes, layers, using standard ggplot2 syntax. Let’s add dark theme plot.  Another situation comes handy want use inspect function get plot way , add additional modifications geom layers based specific use case. Let’s add custom axis labels geom_rug layer.
code: library(ggplot2) # Load ggplot2  inspect_normality(data = penguins,                   vars = c("bill_length_mm", "flipper_length_mm", "body_mass_g"),                   fill_colour = "navyblue",                   title = "Penguin Attributes",                   colour = "lightblue",                   alpha = 0.7) +    theme_dark() # Adds dark theme #> Warning: Removed 6 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`). inspect_normality(data = penguins,                   vars = c("bill_length_mm", "flipper_length_mm", "body_mass_g"),                   fill_colour = "navyblue",                   title = "Penguin Attributes",                   colour = "lightblue",                   alpha = 0.7) +   theme_dark() +    labs(x = "Physical attributes", y = "Count") + # Axis labels   geom_rug(aes(x = value), color = "red", alpha = 0.5) # Geom layer #> Warning: Removed 6 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`).

title: Using quickinspectR
text: ! article, ’ve covered basic use cases, intermediate use cases, even couple advanced use cases push limits quickinspectR. Happy inspecting!

code: @Manual{,   title = {quickinspectR: Quickly Inspect Your Data},   author = {Andrew Fullerton},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.3.7, https://andrewfullerton.github.io/quickinspectR/},   url = {https://github.com/andrewfullerton/quickinspectR}, }

title: Quickly Inspect Your Data
text: goal quickinspectR make easier (quicker) beginner R programmers graphically inspect data. package centered around expanding collection simple inspect functions help users visualize data. Currently, package supports: inspect_normality: graphically inspect distribution numeric variables data. inspect_balance: graphically inspect class balance (lack thereof) data. inspect_missing: graphically inspect missingness data.

title: Quickly Inspect Your Data
text: can install development version quickinspectR GitHub :

title: Quickly Inspect Your Data
text: design, quickinspectR functions require one argument: data frame tibble (data). Unless otherwise specified, functions display relevant variables contained data frame default easy--read plot styling. get started, load package. want see numeric variables data distributed (e.g. check skewed), can use inspect_normality.  want check class imbalance (e.g. unequal distribution classes within categorical variables), can use inspect_balance. Tip: ’re interested key variables data, can use vars argument manually specify variables displayed.  want quickly see ’re missing data (importantly: ’re missing data), can use inspect_missing.  Even though inspect functions run data sole argument, may times want stylize plots bit . make accessible, inspect function contains several additional (completely optional) arguments enable basic plot customization. ’s example using inspect_missing:  advanced plot customization goal quickinspectR, functions built top ggplot2 support advanced customization via additional arguments. learn , can read vignette.
code: library(quickinspectR) inspect_normality(data = iris) inspect_balance(data = palmerpenguins::penguins, vars = c("species", "island")) inspect_missing(data = palmerpenguins::penguins) inspect_missing(data = palmerpenguins::penguins,                 na_colour = "purple", # Change colour used to represent missing values                 fill_colour = "darkgreen", # Change colour used to represent non-missing values                 title = "Missing values in penguins dataset") # Add title

title: Inspect class imbalance — inspect_balance
text: Quickly inspect distribution categorical variables.

title: Inspect class imbalance — inspect_balance
code: inspect_balance(data, vars = NULL, fill_colour = "grey30", title = NULL, ...)

title: Inspect class imbalance — inspect_balance
text: data date frame tibble least one categorical variable. vars vector categorical variables contained data. Default value NULL produce plots every categorical variable data. fill_colour R-supported colour hex code assign barplot colour. Default value "grey30" title string. Default value NULL title. ... Additional ggplot2 parameters modify plot outputs.

title: Inspect class imbalance — inspect_balance
text: ggplot2 object bar plots categorical variable.

title: Inspect class imbalance — inspect_balance
text: inspect_balance uses ggplot2 produce bar plots. valid arguments may passed geom_bar layer may also passed inspect_balance modify plot outputs.

title: Inspect class imbalance — inspect_balance
code: # Basic usage inspect_balance(iris)   # Advanced usage # Manually specifies the variable to inspect and modifies plot output inspect_balance(data = iris,                 c("Species"),                 fill_colour = "blue",                 title = "Class balance of Species")

title: Inspect missing values — inspect_missing
text: Quickly inspect missing values dataset producing bar plot.

title: Inspect missing values — inspect_missing
code: inspect_missing(   data,   vars = NULL,   na_colour = "red",   fill_colour = "grey30",   title = NULL,   ... )

title: Inspect missing values — inspect_missing
text: data non-empty data frame tibble. vars character vector column names inspect. Default value NULL produce plots every variable data. na_colour R-supported colour hex value indicate missing values. Default value "red". fill_colour R-supported colour hex value indicate non-missing values. Default value "grey30". title non-empty string plot title. Default value NULL results title displayed. ... Additional ggplot2 parameters modify plot outputs (e.g., alpha, colour).

title: Inspect missing values — inspect_missing
text: ggplot2 object (bar plot) showing proportion missingness specified variables.

title: Inspect missing values — inspect_missing
text: inspect_missing uses ggplot2 produce bar plot representing proportion missing non-missing values column dataset. valid arguments may passed geom_bar layer ggplot2 may also passed inspect_missing via ... customize plot appearance.

title: Inspect missing values — inspect_missing
code: # Basic usage inspect_missing(airquality)   # Advanced usage: Manually specify variables and modify plot output inspect_missing(data = airquality,                 vars = c("Ozone", "Solar.R"),                 na_colour = "green",                 fill_colour = "blue",                 alpha = 0.5)

title: Inspect normality — inspect_normality
text: Quickly inspect distribution numeric variables.

title: Inspect normality — inspect_normality
code: inspect_normality(   data,   vars = NULL,   fill_colour = "grey30",   title = NULL,   bins = 15,   ... )

title: Inspect normality — inspect_normality
text: data date frame tibble least one numeric variable. vars vector numeric variables contained data. Default value NULL produce plots every numeric variable data. fill_colour R-supported colour hex code assign histogram colour. Default value "grey30" title string. Default value NULL title. bins number specifying number bins used histogram. Default value 15. ... Additional ggplot2 parameters modify plot outputs.

title: Inspect normality — inspect_normality
text: faceted ggplot2 object histograms numeric variable.

title: Inspect normality — inspect_normality
text: inspect_normality uses ggplot2 produce histograms. valid arguments may passed geom_histogram layer may also passed inspect_mortality via ... modify plot outputs.

title: Inspect normality — inspect_normality
code: # Basic usage inspect_normality(iris)   # Advanced usage # Manually specifies the variables to inspect and modifies plot output inspect_normality(data = iris,                   vars = c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width"),                   fill_colour = "blue",                   title = "Distribution of Sepal Length & Width",                   bins = 10)
